Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports projects to explore fundamental issues in Einstein's general theory of relativity (GR). One project examines the evolution of spacetimes to see if the development of singularities that signal the breakdown of GR can occur in nature only inside black holes and, within black holes, can be visible only to observers who run into them. This is called the Cosmic Censorship Conjecture. This question will be addressed through continued development of light­cone­ estimates for the Einstein equations that parallel those that have already been developed for the Yang-­Mills-­Higgs equations. The objective will be to show that space­time curvature cannot blow up (point­wise) in a (vacuum) solution to Einstein's equations until the integrated (Bel­-Robinson) energy for curvature blows up. Another project will be to continue the development of improved numerical methods for the study of black hole collisions. Recent work has established the regularity of the (conformally transformed) ADM evolution equations at null infinity. This result and its potential generalizations will be applied to actual numerical calculations.

The cosmic censorship conjecture is often considered to be the main open mathematical problem in classical general relativity. Cosmic censorship is the natural analogue, for Einstein's equations, of the global existence property for Minkowski space field theories and so it seems very plausible that techniques that have proven successful in the analysis of the latter should have something important to contribute to the former. In addition, any significant progress on the development of improved numerical methods for the analysis of black hole collisions can be anticipated to strongly influence the ongoing worldwide efforts to numerically model these important astrophysical processes and ultimately to impact LIGO and LISA observations. Much of this research should be of interest to mathematicians. Development of improved numerical methods for the computation of gravitational waves from colliding black holes could have an impact on the experimental search for such radiation. Postdoctoral fellows and graduate students are expected to play key roles in these projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Together with Dr. Lars Andersson of the Albert Einstein Institute in Potsdam, Germany the principal investigator established the dynamical stability, in the direction of cosmological expansion, of a large class of cosmological solutions to the Einstein field equations of general relativity. Their results showed that every solution that is sufficiently 'close', in a well-defined mathematical sense, to any one of the given background spacetimes under study decays to that background in the limit of infinite cosmological expansion. Roughly speaking this happens because the gravitational wave 'perturbations' can be proven to 'die out' asymptotically, in a precisely defined sense, as the expansion follows its course. This conclusion holds for the fully nonlinear field equations and not merely for their linearized approximation and even applies to solutions in more than the usual four spacetime dimensions.

This research is aimed at shedding light on the most important unresolved mathematical problem in general relativity—namely the global initial value (or 'Cauchy') problem for Einstein's field equations. The very viability of Einstein's theory as a satisfactory, classical theory of gravitation hinges on the ultimate resolution of this problem. The principal investigator is continuing other, more ambitious efforts in this direction by further developing his program for deriving light-cone estimates for Einstein's equations. Such estimates have already proven their value in the study of various other nonlinear field equations and are expected to play a vital role for the Einstein equations as well. This research should have the broader impact of influencing the mathematical study of still more general nonlinear wave equations in curved spacetimes.

The principal investigator, together with Dr. Oliver Rinne, also of the Einstein Institute, continued his study of the feasibility of putting the outer boundary for numerical gravitational wave calculations literally at infinity (or more precisely at so-called future null infinity). This is an important goal since the energy in gravitational radiation is only precisely defined at null infinity. Since however any computer has only a finite capacity and speed the idea that one can extend the scope of its calculations to an infinite distance in a practical way is not obviously achievable. The investigators were nevertheless able to do this by applying a transformation that maps null infinity onto a finite grid after first showing that the field equations are actually well-behaved under such a transformation—a far from obvious result. They recently extended their earlier developments by generalizing them to allow for the coupling to certain material sources. This research is anticipated to have an ultimate impact on the numerical modeling of sources of gravitational waves and indirectly on the efforts to experimentally detect such waves.

Finally, the principal investigator, together with Prof. Antonella Marini (Yeshiva University) and Dr. Rachel Maitra (Albion College) continued their rigorous development of a new and powerful semi-classical approximation method for interacting quantized fields. They are currently working to apply their techniques to the fundamental problem of quantizing so-called Yang-Mills fields which are crucial to the physics of elementary particles. With (Yale graduate student) Joseph Bae the principal investigator has applied these same methods to an important problem in quantum cosmology and they have obtained some surprising new results that were seemingly beyond the reach of earlier methods. Further work along these lines may shed light on the fundamental problem of how to quantize the gravitational field in a fully covariant way—in accordance with Einstein's fundamental principle.
